Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Collective Effects in Suspensions of Vesicles, Capsules, and Particles

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Award: 1066263
PI: Shaqfeh/Muller

This project represents a comprehensive investigation of the individual dynamics and the collective interactions of vesicles, capsules, and capsule/particle mixtures. The collaborative research is a synergistic effort between high performance computer (HPC) simulations of multiphase flow phenomena as well as detailed experiments using microfluidics and microrheology. Novel aspects of the simulation algorithm include a smooth particle mesh Ewald boundary element code employing both spectral, Loop subdivision, and boundary element resolution of the deforming and interacting interfaces. Essentially, arbitrary shear, bending, and dilatational moduli in the interfacial modeling can be included thus allowing the full range of dynamics from capsules to vesicles including rigid particles and mixtures to be simulated in complex microfluidic geometries. Moreover, nonBrownian and Brownian suspensions can be simulated with high resolution of the interfaces. The experiments include direct visualization, via fluorescence microscopy, of the detailed time varying dynamics of vesicles, and, by creative interfacial chemistry, capsules with varying shear modulus in (a) the microfluidic four roll mill device (capable of reproducing any planar mixed flow in the vicinity of a stagnation point at which the vesicle/capsule may be trapped and observed for extended times) and (b) microchannel geometries designed for examination of collective suspension dynamics. Experiments will also focus on measurements, through fluorescence microscopy and particle tracking, of the shear-induced diffusion of particles and the rheological behavior as the confinement length scale is varied. Applications including understanding platelet hemostasis in the microcirculation as well as engineering vesicles for medical applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A vesicle is a fluid sac surrounded by a membrane, typically composed of a bilayer of phospholipids -- molecules that have water-loving heads and water-hating tails. Vesicles act within our bodies as partitions which transport molecules from one place to another. Synthetic versions are used as drug delivery devices for pharmaceutical applications. Most cell membranes in the body are composed of the same bilayers as the initial building blocks. The dynamics of vesicles under flow is therefore of direct application to both bodily function and drug delivery. Vesicles come in all sizes from tens of nanometers to many microns in diameter. To describe their dynamics over a wide size range is a complex mathematical problem, since the membrane itself is fluid (i.e. the molecules move easily past one another in the same plane), incompressible (i.e. the area of the membrane is fixed) and elastic under bending (i.e. a membrane sheet will tend to snap back when bent). 

We have, throughout the course of this grant, developed a precise mathematical and computational framework for describing the dynamics of vesicles under flow. To do this we used methods taken actually from the graphic arts industry -- methods which allow very smooth surfaces to be defined from only a discrete number of mesh points in space. The need for "smoothness" in defining the shapes of vesicles lies in the fact that bending elasticity, as described previously, is a force that depends on curvature. So precise definitions of curvature need to be mathematically defined in order to apply Newton's laws to the evolution of a vesicle shape. This very precise definition of shape is combined with the solution of the so-called equations of motion for the fluid  both inside and outside the vesicle to create a complete dynamic vesicle flow solver. 

Using this new tool then we examined the physics of single and collections of vesicles in many different flow fields. This allowed us to uncover the physics behind many previously known as well as many new phenomena. For example, in a very simple flow, that between two plates that are moved at different speeds parallel to each other (called simple shear flow) a vesicle can have many dynamic states involving membrane motion and shape change. Previous to this study, it was thought that those states were limited to three types: tank-treading, trembling and tumbling (whose motions are well described by their names!). However, there are many other three dimensional states which were not discovered because they were inaccessible until the appropriate numerical tool was applied. Similarly, in a flow that is simple, but somewhat different -- an extensional or stretching flow -- we discovered that a steady vesicle shape does not always exist and it can evolve in time even in a very highly asymmetric form (see FIg. 1). Moreover, at high deformations, it can form "pearls" (see Fig. 2) small "subvesicles" on a vesicle string. The formation of these pearls and the conditions of their formation was not understood in flow until the numerical simulations and subsequent analysis demonstrated their physical origin. 

Thus combining careful mathematical analysis, with the tools of graphic image analysis has allowed the understanding of the physical principles behind the flow dynamics of one of natures building blocks -- the vesicle.
